text: Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: - um that the side effects from the hormone therapies were getting a little bit too much for you. Patient: Yes. Doctor: And your preference, which I agreed with at the time, was to stop the Lupron you get. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: And given that your PSA level is very low, it was an investment point level, that you basically stop that, allow the testosterone to recover if you did good by itself, and then to monitor the PSA to see where that was at. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So on the one hand, it does move over time, if the testosterone continues to increase, which it probably will, may feed the cancer. But on the other hand, in the meantime, your quality of life should be better than it would have been with a testosterone let’s say less than twenty. Patient: Okay. That’s’ Doctor: So it’s kind of the choice that we made, and this is sort of the natural expectation of what we were expecting to see. Patient: You would recommend having it done Doc? Doctor: No. There’s no evidence that people like you that people like you in controlling cancer. Patient: You know I was reading an article a while back that I like about it’s going to become common for folks to live into their hundreds.

text: Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So how are things going since the last time I saw you a couple months ago? Patient: I’m feelin’ fine. Well, let’s put it this way… Energy, lack of energy. That’s my number one complaint. Doctor: Okay. Is that getting any better, any worse or staying the same? Patient: I - It appears to be getting worse. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I don’t know, I…maybe it’s age. Doctor: You’re not that old yet. (laughs) Patient: Oh. (chuckles) Doctor: That’s young, in this day and age. Patient: Yeah. Uh-huh. Doctor: Any other new symptoms? So fatigue is maybe a bit worse? Patient: I feel so; I, I uh I govern that by my ability to you know do things around the house. So whether it’s supporting activities, playing golf I don’t have any energy. And possibly because I’m a little heavier now, too. I’ve gained a few pounds.

Patient: No. I’m good with the morphine.

text: Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: We have a clinical trial where we’re giving the chemotherapy and everybody gets an infusion two to three times a week. So- Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: for someone coming from F___ may it may be too much to come in here that often, but we’re giving Vitamin C to half the people and half the people don’t because some data says that Vitamin C may reduce the side effects of the chemotherapy and also help the benefit. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: But we don’t know that. It could be just folly; it could be the truth- Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: And so half the people get it, half the people don’t- Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: but you still have to come in and get an infusion three times a week. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: And so that one is logistically pretty tough. But that is something that you know if we’re going chemotherapy, I can make sure we get you the permission slip or the consent form to let you know what that would look like.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
